loans.name: Nicolasa

texts.en:
Nicolasa C., 51, is one person who definitely has the motivation to follow her dreams. She finished only high school but is confident that she will become a successful micro entrepreneur. Nicky, as she is called by friends, is married to Emildo, a motorcycle taxi driver. They reside in Parola, Binondo, at the heart of Manila and together they are raising three children. One of them studies in college, another is in elementary school, while the third stays at home.

Nicky has run her own sari-sari (variety) store at home for two years now. She sells goods at a cheap per-piece price to accommodate the immediate needs of her neighbors, such as a sachet of shampoo for an employee who needs to bathe before going to work, or a small amount of salt that a cook needs to season her food. Nicky is also into the buy and sell business. With these, she earns roughly PHP 11,000 per month.

To help her grow her business, Nicky has requested a loan of PHP 14,000. With this she plans to buy four sacks of rice, which she will repackage for retail. She also intends to purchase more grocery items to add to the various products on her store shelves. With this loan, she knows she will be able to earn more profits and save more.

Nicky's biggest challenge is that she has lists of debts that her customers sometimes fail to pay because of financial constraints. But being the determined micro entrepreneur that she is, she seeks a solution to this problem. This is all for the purpose of achieving her dream of having a profitable business, a good life, and a sustained education for her children.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase four sacks of rice and groceries

loans.name: Rodrigo

texts.en:
Mr. Rodrigo B., 53 years of age, is a resident of Digson, Bonifacio, Miss. Occ. He is married to Eleonor B.. 

For his way of living, he is a security guard of Vabgrec Security and Allied Services, Inc. Now he is earning an average net income of not less than PHP 10,000 a month. He is also earning for his monthly pension from the armed forces. 

He joined PAGLAUM MPC in the year 2011 because he is very much interested with our products and services and for being one of the most outstanding cooperative in Northern Mindanao and the awarded coop for being Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006. As a 1st cycle loaner, he is given a privilege to avail an amount of P15,000.00 for the renovation of his house.

loans.use: To renovate his house

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok L., born in 1962, is a villager who lives in Preaek Hour Lech village in Kandal province. She earns a small income to support her famiL. by working as a vegetable seller in the local market.

She is a widow with three children: one is a security guard, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the youngest is a student. 

The two eldest face difficulties in getting to their workplaces due to the fact that they work far from the famiL. home. For this reason, Mrs. Sok L. would like to ask for a loan in order to add to her savings in order to eventualL. purchase a motorcycle to provide her children with reliable transportation.

loans.use: To add to her savings in order to eventually purchase a motorcycle to provide her children with reliable transportation to work

loans.name: Hou's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of nine members located in Preaek Hour Lech village in Kandal province. Mrs. Hou S. P. was born in 1969 and is the group leader, selected by the other members. 

Her husband, Mr. Mann P., works as an electrician for a company, which enables him to earn a small salary to support his family. This couple has four children. Three are students and also support their mother's business; the youngest one is 5 years old and not in school yet. 

Mrs. Hou S. P. sells groceries in the local village. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to support her purpose.

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Anatalia

texts.en:
Anatalia N. is from the village of Brgy. Bone North, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 32 years old. Anatalia is single. 

To make a living, Anatalia prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Anatalia has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2011, Anatalia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Anatalia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Anatalia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products

location.town: Brgy. Bone North, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Ediza

texts.en:
The beginning does not always determine the end. For Ediza R., 41, a poor educational background will not necessarily end in poverty. Ediza did not even reach high school. She is married to Freddie, a factory worker. They have two children, who are both in elementary school. Their family resides in Binondo, Manila.

To fight off poverty, Ediza set up a sari-sari (variety) store at their home, by which she also helps her fellow community members by providing them with what they need most: basic toiletries and instant food, among other things. She has been running her sari-sari store for five years now. Aside from that, she also repackages garlic and onions and includes them in her sets of products for sale. These enable her to earn 12,000 PHP monthly. 

To help her continue operation of her business, she would like to request a 16,000 PHP loan. She knows that sufficient finances on hand will ensure that she will have enough products in her store to meet the various needs of her community. Basically, she plans to buy additional products for her store.

Just like any ordinary sari-sari store owner, it is her struggle to go after customers who do not pay their debts on time. But a strategic microentrepreneur like Ediza finds ways to solve such problems. Ediza is focused on growing her store into a big grocery someday. She desires to prove that her failure in terms of her education will not be experienced by her children, whom she hopes will finish their schooling well.

As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meetings, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she received.
	
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase products for her store

loans.name: Mork's Group

texts.en:
The nine people who have formed this village bank loan live in Preaek Ta Sau village in Kandal province. Mrs. Mork C., born in 1971, is the village bank president. She was selected for this position by the other members. 

Her husband, Mr. Him Vannak, earns a small income to support his family by selling bread in the local village. Since this business is going well, her husband would like to start selling bread door-to-door. For this reason, Mrs. Mork C. is requesting a loan to add to her savings in order to buy a motorcycle for her husband's business. With the rest of the loan, she plans to buy more bread so as to enlarge her husband's business. 

Mrs. Mork C. is a stay-at-home mother who prepares the family meals and maintains the household. This couple has four children: two are employed as seamstresses in the garment factory, and the other two attend the local school.

loans.use: To add her savings in order to buy a motorcycle for her husband's business as well as to buy more bread for her husband to offer for sale

She plans to use the remainder of the loan to buy fertilizers and gasoline. Aside from farming, she also adds to her income by knitting.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:

The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk food, and toothpaste, in the local community. She also buys and sells gold dust and rice by the kilogram. Eva has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2009, Eva joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eva has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Eva is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods and junk food. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Eva from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

He says that this will help improve his production and earn him more income. He hopes that in the near future his production will increase and that he will be able to export his flowers. He comments that his future is bright as a farmer because he can access financial assistance from Juhudi.

loans.name: Fe Compo's Group

texts.en:
Fe C. is from the village of Labo, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 44 years old, married, and has  two school-aged and two adult children. She is the group leader of this four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Fe C.’s Group". 


To make a living, Fe owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Fe joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

Fe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and pesticides. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About PMPC:  

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. 

About Group Loans
In a group loan, each member of the group receives an individual loan but is part of a group of individuals bound by a group guarantee. Under this arrangement, each member of the group supports one another and is responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: used to purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent K. has a mixed farm in Litein town, Rift Valley, Kenya that produces vegetables, potatoes, tomatoes, tea, maize and milk, all sold locally. He has been in the farming business for fifteen years. 

Vincent is 57 years old and married with seven children whose ages range from 13 to 26. Four of them are currently attending school.

He has requested a loan of 60,000Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He says that with this cow, his family will be guaranteed enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. He hopes that in the next five years his dairy farming will have improved to the point where he can acquire two quality dairy cows and build a diary unit.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita A. is from the village of Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old. Teresita is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2004, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Estela

texts.en:
Estela O. is from the village of Samay, Gingoog City. She is 55 years old. Estela is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Estela owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & toothpaste in the local community. Estela has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Estela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estela is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Estela from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Narciso

texts.en:
Narciso D. is from the village of Nabbotuan, Solana, Cagayan. He is 58 years old. Narciso is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Narciso owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Narciso has been engaged in his business for over 39 years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Narciso joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narciso is requesting a loan of 22,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Narciso from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene N. is from Labo, Ozamiz City. She is 42 years old. Arlene is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Arlene owns and operates a business making and selling foods. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Arlene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. She is now requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Arlene from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina C. is from the village of Samay, Gingoog City. She is 41 years old. Rosalina is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalina owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks & other delicacies like hot cakes, sweet potato and banana cues (bananas on a stick) in the local community. Rosalina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Rosalina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalina is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale such as flour and ripe bananas. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rosalina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients such as flour and ripe bananas

loans.name: Japhet

texts.en:
Japhet is a dairy farmer from Litein town in the Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been in the farming business for ten years and sells his milk through Brookside Company. He also earns income from his small-scale farming of tea which is sold locally.

He has requested a loan of 40,000Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to improve his dairy farming. The extra income from this loan will help him expand his business and improve his family's livelihood. He says that his biggest challenges have been diseases and the fluctuating market price of milk.

Japhet is 28 years old and single.

loans.use: To improve his dairy farming.

loans.name: Roldan

texts.en:
This is Roldan C., 29, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Corazon C., a plant retailer, and father to their children. By the grace of God, Roldan has managed to support his children's schooling. At this time, he is working hard to send his children all the way through college, a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Roldan as he himself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Roldan is a landscaping artist who decorates gardens. He and his wife aesthetically alter the view of any plain garden or patio for a specific fee. His wife provides the plants needed for the transformation. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. 
 
To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php 19,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy plants, ornamental rocks, grasses and other landscaping needs. He expects a boost in his income as he expands his business.  

Roldan dreams of being able to give his children a good, high quality education through all his hard work on his business. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy plants, ornamental rocks, grasses and other landscaping needs

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:

To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling health & medicinal products in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Lolita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Lolita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

He started as an agriculturalist five years back and later set up a beer depot. He lives in Kyenjojo and his family dream is to educate his children.

To make a living, Lorna owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling homemade sausage or "chorizzo" in the local community. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Lorna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale such as ground pork. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lorna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Milyn's Group

texts.en:
Milyn A. is from the village of Labo, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 28 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Milyn is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Milyn A.’s Group".

To make a living, Milyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Milyn has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Milyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Milyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the third taken out by Milyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: used to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Andrew

texts.en:
Andrew, 51, is married with 8 children between 10 and 28 years. Four of the children are currently attending school. He has been farming for the last twelve years and sells his milk to a local cooling plant and tea to the local market. 

He has requested a loan of 50,000Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. His primary challenge has been lack of enough animal feed.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch H. is a 54-year-old widower who lives in the province of Kompong Cham. To earn a living, Touch H. drives a motor taxi. Usually, he makes a profit of approximately $3 per day to help meet the whole family’s needs. He was married but his wife died many years ago. He lives with three married children and one who is single. Touch H. says his single son is going to get married soon and he doesn’t have enough money to help him hold the wedding ceremony. To solve this problem, Touch H. is requesting a loan from Kiva to arrange his son's wedding ceremony which will be coming soon.

loans.use: For his son's wedding ceremony

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith T. is from Gango, Ozamiz City. She is 47 years old. Judith is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Judith owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Judith has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Judith joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Judith is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Judith from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Modesto

texts.en:
This is Modesto D., 43, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. He is a vendor who manages his household and business while helping out his family. As of the present time he is busy providing income for their everyday expenses.

Modesto sells fruits and vegetables. His main products are seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines like pineapples, which are grown mostly in the south, region of Luzon. Also in his product inventory are garlic and onions, tomatoes and other staples for simple recipes. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy additional fruits and vegetables to be incorporated into his current product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.  

Modesto dreams of being able to see his business grow and mature. He also dreams of having his own children who will carry on his entrepreneurship spirit. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy additional fruits and vegetables to be incorporated into his current product inventory

loans.name: Benson

texts.en: Benson would like a loan to buy fuel, soap and sugar for resale. He has a retail shop and his home area is Kyenjojo, Uganda. He intends to expand his business and educate his children.

loans.use: Buying fuel, soap and sugar for resale

loans.name: Rizza

texts.en:
Rizza O. is from the village of Samay, Gingoog City. She is 31 years old. Rizza is single and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rizza owns & operates a bakeshop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from baking & selling a variety of staple products including bread in the local community. Rizza has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Rizza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rizza is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional cooking ingredients such as flour and eggs. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rizza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional cooking ingredients like flour and eggs

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a retail shop for the past three years, selling to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also sells movie tapes which contributes to her other source of income. Eunice hopes to establish a studio in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of beans, rice, peas and sugar. She decided to join Yehu because it has no legal requirements.

loans.use: To  purchase sacks of beans, rice, peas and sugar

loans.name: Ma. Brenda

texts.en:
Ma. Brenda is a 50-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two businesses: making and selling rope and selling vegetables. She lives in Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,800. Ma. Brenda is borrowing PHP 12,000 to purchase raw materials. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Brenda aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel would like a loan to modernize his livestock farm. He is a commercial farmer who started on a small scale five years ago. He is charged with the responsibility of taking care of his seven children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He desires to educate his children and make his business permanent. However, price fluctuations and seasonal changes affect his business.

loans.use: Improvement  of  his livestock farm

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
This is Virginia M., 58, resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Ricardo M., a farmer, and mother to their three children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Virginia operates a variety store where she also sells the fruit that her husband grows and harvests. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also invest a portion of the loan for their fruit stall needs. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Virginia hopes to be able to expand further soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Mbogo Group

texts.en:
Mohamed A., who is in his early thirties, is married with two children.  He has had a charcoal business for three years now.  He works from 2:00am to 6:00pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Mohamed's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He hopes for a loan to increase his charcoal stock. His dream is to sell charcoal at wholesale prices and to send his kids to higher education.

Mohamed will share this loan with his loan group, Mbogo, which has a total of 19 members.  The members of the group will hold each other responsible in paying back the loans.

In the picture, Mohamed is in blue, first on the right.

loans.use: To increase his charcoal stock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Wilhelma

texts.en:
Wilhelma D. C. is from the village of Taguilon. She is 64 years old. Wilhelma is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Wilhelma raises native chickens for sale. Wilhelma is also engaged in other businesses in the retail sector, primarily selling a variety of goods in the local community in her sari-sari store.

In 2007, Wilhelma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilhelma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Wilhelma is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Wilhelma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Swaibu

texts.en: Thirty-year-old Swaibu would like a loan to purchase a motor vehicle. He is  involved in a transport business and phone charging. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda and his desire is to put up a permanent residential house.

loans.use: Purchase of motor vehicle

loans.name: Keki Group

texts.en:
Zainabu C., who is in her mid-thirties, is married with four children.  She has had a charcoal business for two years now. She works from 7:00am to 6:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Zainabu's 4th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase her stock of charcoal and started selling charcoal at wholesale price.  She has paid back the priovious loans successfully. She hopes for a loan to pay school fees. Her dream is to take her children to higher education.

Zainabu will share this loan with her loan group Keki, which has a total of 17 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Zainabu is in the back row with a head scarf.

loans.use: To pay for school fees.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
This is Victoria P., 52, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She has two children. Together with her children, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Victoria operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Victoria hopes to be able to expand further soon, just as she hopes to purchase some material needs for herself and her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel C. is from the village of Samay, Gingoog City. He is 27 years old. Joel is single. To make a living, Joel owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks & other delicacies like homemade pizzas & hot cakes in the local community. Joel has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Joel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale such as flour and eggs. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Joel from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mulwa

texts.en:
Mulwa is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school, while three already graduated from school.  She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a clothes-selling business for the past three years, selling in a shop to her neighbours especially women's clothes. Mulwa hopes to establish a stall to sell her clothes from in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu because it is simple to join.

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret M. has a restaurant, which she has had for over 10 years. She is 34 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala Central Region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.

To help expand her business, Gorret has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more stock of food.  With the help of this loan, Gorret hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Gorret hopes to build rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of food

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is a 54-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a sari-sari (general) store and selling food. She lives in Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable and improving her cash flow. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 30,000. Magdalena is borrowing PHP 16,000 to purchase more stocks to sell.  This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Magdalena aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: For additional working capital

To help expand his business, William has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase car engine oil and spare parts for resale.  With the help of this loan, William hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children.  In the future, William hopes to expand his business.

loans.name: Bella's Group

texts.en:
Bella T. is from the village of San Pascual Diffun Quirino. She is 37 years old. Bella is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Bella T. group.

Bella is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Bella owns & operates a furniture making business, making & selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Bella has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Bella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Bella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Bella is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will again be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Bella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Reli Group

texts.en:
Fatuma S., in her mid twenties, is married and has twin daughters. She has been selling clothes door-to-door for three years now. She works from 2.00pm to 4.00pm, just two hours. This is because, she goes to deliver the clothes to customers when her children go to school and she collects her dues at the same time. She then hurries home before they come back from school.

This will be Fatuma's loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She hopes for a loan to save for school fees. Her dreams is to build a house of her own. Fatuma will share this loan with her loan group, Reli, which has a total of 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the picture, Fatuma is 1st on the left in an orange dress.

loans.use: To save for school fees.

loans.name: Ana Editha

texts.en:
This is Ana Editha C., 40, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She has two children, both of whom are already enrolled in college. By the grace of God, Editha has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continue supporting her children’s education all the way through college. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents, like Editha, as she herself has been a college graduate (she is a graduate of Bachelor of Science in Nursing). She believes that a college diploma is the best legacy that parents could leave to their children.

Ana Editha operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is to buy general merchandise from wholesalers and then sell them piecemeal, with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ana Editha dreams to be able to live happily and contented because she believes that she will live a better life and manage her business more efficiently if she is happy. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory.

A "Motisha" loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. Theresia has paid back her 1st "motisha" loan successfully. She hopes to obtain a loan to start selling charcoal at wholesale prices.

Theresia will share this loan with her loan  group, "Subira", which has a total of 12 members.  The members of the group will hold each other responsible in paying back the loan.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a single woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a fish selling business for the past four years, selling at the market to her neighbors. Mwanasha's major challenge is seasonality. During rainy season, the demand for fish is lower and the supply is higher. She hopes to open a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase a fridge for storing fish and add sacks of fish. She decided to join Yehu because of its simple formation.

texts.en: K. Agatha began her banana sales business 2 years ago. The 49-year-old, happily married mother of 4 says before she ventured into her current trade, she was operating a used-clothing sales enterprise. Agatha says one of her closest friends was behind the decision to change businesses. This business, which she operates from Ntungamo food market, generates her 100,000 UGX, weekly. Agatha, who belongs to Abarihamwe Women's group, says she is requesting this loan to purchase other foods such as cassava, maize and potatoes to sell.

loans.name: Sea

texts.en: Sea L., 42, is married and resides with her two children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. L. and her husband sell rice and raise pigs, earning an income of 3 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 98 USD on food and 23 USD on the other necessary expenses. L. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to purchase more rice and pigs to expand the current business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more rice and pigs to expand the current business

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma is a married woman who lives in Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a food vending business. Her husband Rolando, who is 35 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living. They have two children who are 5 and 7 years old, respectively. Vilma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Vilma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital to continue to save up for future business expansion. Vilma is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: Additional working capital

Shaibu would share this loan with his loan group, Nazareth, which has a total of 15 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

Nushik says she is busy at her farm in the early morning and in the evening.  During daylight hours, she works at an agricultural production trading organization.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
This is Dolores O., 51, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Felipe, a tricycle driver, and mother to their children. By the grace of God, Dolores has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Dolores, as she herself is a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Dolores operates a charcoal retailing business along with her buying and selling of tropical fruits. She also oversees the tricycle transport business. In the Philippines, many still use the old ways of cooking (on an earthen stove where charcoal is used) to save money. Charcoal is much cheaper than LPG fuel, which, in the current market, costs as much as Php600.   Many people prefer to buy charcoal, which is so cheap that it can be bought for Php5. More people are also switching to firewood, which can be foraged or found in the trash.  Dolores also sells tropical fruits on her stall because they are usually requested by her customers.  Among these three businesses, she earns an estimated net income of around Php9,000 monthly.
 
To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of charcoal in sacks to be repackaged and retailed to her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Dolores hopes to be able to see her business mature and grow. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of charcoal in sacks to be repackaged, and also varieties of tropical fruits to add to her current inventory

loans.name: Eligio

texts.en:
This is Eligio B., 52, a resident of Silang, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Josephina B., a housewife, and is father to their children. By the grace of God, Eligio has managed to support his children's schooling. At this time, he is working hard to send his children all the way through college. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Eligio, as he himself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Eligio operates their jeepney service, which is basically used for public transportation.  He is also a farmer who grows, tends and harvests his own crop from his land. He mostly grows seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines, like pineapples, which are grown mostly in the south region of Luzon. Also in his product inventory are garlic and onions, tomatoes and other staples for simple cooking recipes. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a small income of around Php400 every day on his jeepney operation.

To help him continue the operation of his business, he is requesting a Php9,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy fertilizers, seedlings and other farming needs for the crop. He will also use part of this loan to pay for the cost of renewing the registration of his jeepney. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 
 
Eligio dreams to be able to give his children a good and high quality education through all his hard work in his business. He faithfully meets with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: For the renewal of the registration for his jeepney, and for planting materials for his farm

Chiziwi is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a Kikois-selling business from home for the past two years, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Chiziwi faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  She hopes to be self-reliant in the future.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To  purchase bales of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson is a forty-seven year-old married man, living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda.  The responsibility of looking after six of his children solely rests on him, and his desire is to educate them up to University.
For twenty-three years he has been growing onions and distilling alcohol. He started distilling four jerricans of  alcohol in a month but can now distill ten of them. He has a hardship of price fluctuation, and his dream is to supply alcohol to the whole region. Johnson needs the loan to buy bananas for alcohol distilling.

loans.use: Buying bananas for alcohol distilling.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a married woman who lives in Cadiiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a business venture selling fish. Her husband Bernie, who is 43 years old, works as a fish vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have five children who are between 11 and 21 years old. Sonia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 20 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Sonia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10.000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 21st loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for fish vending so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children & for house improvements. Sonia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org.

loans.use: Additional capital for fish vending

Mercedita is borrowing PHP 20,000 to fund operations. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Mercedita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is a twenty-five year-old married man with a child, living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda.  He is longing to buy land and build a permanent house for his residence. For three years, he has been doing a number of activities, such as building, growing maize, and operating shops, which enabled him to live a modest life. He started with a retail shop but he now sells at wholesale.  He is faced with a challenge of price fluctuation of agricultural produce.  His dream is to own an estate. Daniel needs the loan to prepare land and plant maize.

loans.use: Preparation of land for maize plantation.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn, 48 years old, lives in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She is a widow and raises her children by herself.

Evelyn is a farmer. She wakes up early in the morning to prepare food for her kids and then proceeds to her farming duties. She plants and harvests rice and corn crops. Evelyn works hard to raise her kids well and maintain their farm. She hopes for her business to be stable.

Evelyn needs additional fertilizers and other farm inputs. She requested a loan of 6000 PHP from CEVI. Evelyn needs this loan to improve her harvest.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional fertilizers and other farm inputs

Her husband Romeo, who is 61 years old, works as a farmer/carpenter to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have 2 children who are 16 and 31 years old. Gleceria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gleceria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. loans.name: Mathias

texts.en:
Mathias M. K. is thirty four years old and married. His wife is a business woman and they have three children, aged between twelve years old and three years old, whom they hope to give a quality education up to the university level. He sells fruits and vegetables to the local people. He uses a rickshaw to move from one place to another, serving the Central Business District of Mombasa. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, including the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 
Mathias has been in this business for the last ten years now. He says that this business is profitable.  The major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more fruits and vegetables to grow his business and meet the demands of his customers. He dreams of becoming a big supplier of fruits and vegetables to the coastal hotels. He describes himself as trustworthy, honest and courteous.

loans.use: Fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Wafa

texts.en:
Wafa is a mother of three sons. Wafa and her husband are employed with a decent salary. Wafa and her husband run a small store to increase their income. The store is bringing in good income which covers household expenses and gives the family the chance to save.

During the last year and due to economic hardships, Wafa and her husband bought goods on credit. Now that their situation is much better, they want to pay back their suppliers. Wafa, who was photographed in FATEN's branch in Tulkarem, took a loan from FATEN for this purpose.

loans.use: Paying for goods for their store

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya, where she has been farming for six years. She earns her income from the sale of eggs and tea in the local market. Janet is 27 years old and married with three children whose ages range between 2 and 10.

Janet has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings through Juhudi Kilimo for poultry farming. This loan will enable her to increase the number of her chickens and will help increase her income. She hopes that in the next five years she will have more than 500 chickens. Her biggest challenge has been lack of a stable market for eggs.

loans.use: For poultry farming

loans.name: Erlita

texts.en:
Erlita D. is from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City. She is 55 years old. Erlita is widowed and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Erlita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from making and selling snacks & other delicacies like rice cakes, fruit salad, cheese cakes, cassava cakes in the local community. Erlita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Erlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional ingredients & working capital. Erlita is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients, like flour and eggs, needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Erlita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients, like flour and eggs, needed to make products for sale.

Ilyn works hard to sustain her family and also be able to help her extended family.

Ilyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Ilyn is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Iman is a young woman from Tulkarem. She works in a tailoring workshop, and her husband works in the land on the other side of the wall. 

Iman and her husband saved money from their work and started a small grocery store and are starting a small farm in their backyard in Tulkarem. They have a couple of goats. They want to expand their herd and start producing dairy products as Iman's work is seasonal and her husband's work is not stable.

Iman, who appears in the picture above, took a loan from FATEN to purchase a vehicle to distribute the dairy products they produce and neighboring houses' orders from the supermarket.

loans.use: Purchase a goods transportation vehicle

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby is a married woman who lives in Talisay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  a general store, an electronic shop and a mineral water sales business. Her husband Marino, who is 60 years old, works as a technician to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 26 and 32 years old. Ruby joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 28 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ruby has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. This time, for her 29th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to buy items for her store and mineral water so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Ruby is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a father of one son, and he has been working in a blacksmith workshop since he finished vocational school. He saved enough money to start his own workshop four years ago. The workshop is slowly growing  and developing its own clientele. Mahmoud does blacksmith work for houses such as windows and doors.

Mahmoud took a loan from FATEN to purchase a more advanced iron cutting machine which will increase the workshop's productivity. Mahmoud's son is at school.

Mahmoud was photographed in FATEN's office in Nablus.

loans.use: Purchase a more advanced iron-cutting machine

loans.name: Phean

texts.en: The man in the picture is Phean S., 21, who sells firewood. He usually works eight hours a day, selling in and around Siem Reap province. Phean S. buys firewood in bulk from his suppliers. His wife’s name is Keo Sochea. She is 21 and works with him in the same business. This family typically generates an average of $4 US [a day] to cover the family expenses. They are blessed with one young child who is still not enrolled in school. Phean S. will use his loan to add to his saving for a motorbike in order to run a motor taxi service for additional income.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for a motor taxi service

loans.name: Shirley's Group

texts.en:
Shirley I. is from the village of Villa Peña Cabarroguis Quirino. She is 36 years old. Shirley is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Shirley I..

Shirley is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Shirley owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Shirley has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Shirley joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Shirley has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Shirley is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Shirley from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Asokera Development Group-Jinja

texts.en: Betty N. is a 38 year old self-driven and happily married mother of 2.   She is affiliated with Asokera Development group-Jinja. She has been running a tailoring enterprise for 4 years now in Mutai-Jinja. She says that she took over this enterprise from her late mom. Prior to that she was mostly doing farming. Weekly, she says this business generates her 40,000shillings and she is requesting this loan to purchase another sewing machine. She reckons this will boost her business in terms of increased sales revenue, as she will be able to make more clothes with a new machine.

loans.use: The purchase of a new sewing machine

Kasem is requesting a $3000 loan to extend the shop and for advertising. He is planning to expand and open another branch.

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old and lives with eight other family members. In 2009, Houssein decided to open his own barber shop after having gained experience in this field. He is well known in his area and has a good reputation.

Houssein is requesting a $1200 loan to decorate his shop. He aims to improve his business and his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To decorate the shop

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes S. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old. Agnes is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Agnes owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from the buying and selling of fish, like sardines & milk fish, in the local community. Agnes has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Agnes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agnes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Agnes is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish, like salmon & mackerel. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Agnes from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish, like salmon & mackerel

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Sou S. is a 44-year-old woman and the mother of five children, all of whom are still single and work in different jobs. She currently sells a few soft drinks and cooked ingredients in the village. Mostly her clients are neighbors who live near her house. Her husband helps feed the family by working as a requirement worker. The family's living conditions are now suffering due to their house needing repair. To solve the problem, Sou S. would like a loan to repair a part of her broken house.

loans.use: To repair a part of her broken house

loans.name: Romelo

texts.en:
Romelo O. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. He is 39 years old. Romelo is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Romelo owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish, like sardines & milk fish, in the local community. He also makes and sells snacks, like bibingka (a variety of rice cake).  Romelo has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Romelo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romelo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Romelo is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Romelo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.
