loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet M. is from the town of Banga. She is 47 years old. Janet is married and has a 14-year-old child. To make a living, Janet owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Janet has been engaged in farming for 25 years now.

Janet joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janet has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Janet is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Ronie

texts.en:
Ronie R. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. He is 30 years old. Ronie is married and has 2 school-aged children. 

To make a living, Ronie sells seafood products, including fish such as sardines and milk fish, in the local community.  He has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Ronie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. That loan was used to purchase additional inventory & use as working capital for his business. 

Ronie is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell, like salmon and mackerel. This loan will be his 3rd loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand his  business.

loans.name: Nasr

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 23 years old and lives with seven other family members. In 2007, Nasr opened his own barber shop. He is well known in his area and has a good reputation.

Nasr is requesting a $2400 loan to decorate his shop and buy new barber chairs. He aims to improve his business and his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To decorate the shop and buy new barber chairs

loans.name: Sari

texts.en:
Sari K. is  33 years old.  She is married and resides with her four children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for its rubber plantations. Sari sells fish, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband operates a tractor for hire, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family must  spend USD 91 on food and USD 30 on other necessary expenses. 

Sari is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy  more fish to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Jensen Laurette

texts.en:
Jensen Laurette M., 30 years old, is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 2 children aged 7 and 2. To make a living, Jensen Laurette plants and harvests rice for sale. Jensen also grows pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them to her community.

Jensen Laurette joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. 

Jensen Laurette is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to buy farm supplies and pig feeds. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies and pig feeds

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora C. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 52 years old. Teodora is married and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Teodora owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling seafood products  including fish like sardines & milk fish in the local community. Teodora has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Teodora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teodora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Teodora is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell like salmon & mackerel. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Teodora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell like salmon & mackerel

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah C. is from Lower Dicayas, Dipolog City. She is 40 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Hannah owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily snacks and other delicacies, in schools and in the local community. Hannah has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earn approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Hannah joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Hannah is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make snacks to sell. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make snacks to sell

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios R. is from the village of Sta. Cruz, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old. Remedios is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Remedios sells seafood products, including fish like sardines & mackerel in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Remedios joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI. That loan was used to purchase additional inventory & use as working capital to run her business. 

Remedios is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell, such as milk fish and salmon. This loan will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila A. is from the village of Nazareth, Osmeña, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 52 years old,  is widowed, and has two adult children.

Leonila owns and operates a a food stall selling fruits, vegetables, herbs and spices in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately PHP 6,000 a month.

In 2008, Leonila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 6,000 from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Leonila is requesting a new loan of PHP 10,000 which will again be used to purchase fresh fruits and vegetables to sell. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from this loan investment to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fresh fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia W. M. is a married woman.  She and her husband have four children aged between thirteen years old and one year old. 

Julia's business is located at Mikindani estate in Mombasa, Kenya.  Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites and its Indian Ocean white beaches.  Julia owns a fruit and vegetable kiosk.  In addition to this, she also has a business charging batteries.  They also own rental houses which her husband manages.    

Julia has been in business for the last nine years and has managed to provide employment to one person. She says that business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraint.  However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well.  She is using her loan of Kes 70,000 to buy more fruits and vegetables and to add water pipes and taps to their rental houses.  She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. 

Julia describes herself as a welcoming and open-minded person.

loans.use: To buy fruits & vegetables to sell, and add pipes/taps to rental houses

loans.name: Kenneth Joy

texts.en:
Kenneth Joy M. is from the town of Banga.  She is 22 years old, married, and has a 2-year-old child. To make a living, Kenneth Joy plants and harvests rice for sale. She works hard to save for her child's future.

Kenneth Joy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She  has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI, and is now requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to buy seeds and fertilizers to prepare her next harvest.

loans.use: To buy  seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma B. is from the barangay (village) of Galas, in Dipolog City. She is 56 years old, married, and has 2 adult children. Alma operates a family member's business in the clothing sector, selling ready-to-wear (RTW) clothing in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2006, Alma joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC of 70,000 PHP, which was used to purchase materials to renovate her store. Alma is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory for the RTW business. This will be the 28th loan Alma has taken out from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase clothing inventory

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes B. is from the village of San Isidro, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old, is married, and has 10 adult children. To make a living, Agnes owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, and toothpaste in the local community. Agnes also has a part-time tailoring service repairing curtains and bed sheets. She has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Agnes joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI of 9000 PHP, which was used for working capital and to purchase additional inventory. Agnes is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory such as canned goods and snack foods. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc. (HSPFI) is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase inventory such as canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en: Chhorn C. makes a living working in construction in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. He has been working in this job since 2002. He usually generates a profit of about $3.33 each day to help support his family. He has a life partner in his wife, who is a mat seller. The couple has six children, three of whom are employed in different paying jobs. Chhorn C. would like a loan of $900 in order to purchase a piece of land in good condition for a farming business. He will rent out this land to farmers for a fee.

loans.use: To purchase a piece of land that he can farm and rent to other farmers

loans.name: Mediadora

texts.en:
Mediadora A. is from the village of Imelda, in the municipality of Labason, in the province of Zamboanga del Norte. She is 57 years old, is widowed, and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Mediadora owns and operates a business venture making instant salabat (ginger tea). While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for her business comes from selling instant salabat in the local community. Mediadora has been engaged in her business for more than 30 years and earns approximately 1000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2011, Mediadora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used as working capital and to purchase additional inventory. This will be Mediadora's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To provide working capital and purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Tweyambe Women's Group-Jinja

texts.en:
36-year-old K. Oliver makes common cause with Tweyambe Women's Group-Jinja.  She has been at the helm of her business selling used clothing at the Jinja market for 8 years. To take root in this trade, she banked on savings from her agro produce sales business.

This happily married mother of 2 says running her business has been worthwhile in many ways. She points to the improving standards of living of her family as a case in point. She makes 180,000 shillings in profits weekly from her business.

K. Oliver requests this loan to purchase a new sewing machine that she plans to use to sew clothes herself, which she will sell at a higher price.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa A. is from the village of Antonino, in the municipality of Labason, in the province of Zamboanga del Norte. She is 60 years old, is married, and has 8 adult children. To make a living, Elisa owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Elisa has been engaged in her business for more than 3 years and earns approximately 2000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC of 3000 PHP, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elisa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 2nd loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mary Joy

texts.en:
Mary Joy G. is from the town of Banga. She is 33 years old.  She is married and has 3 children, aged 2, 4, and 10. To make a living, Mary Joy owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Mary Joy dreams for her children to be successful someday.

Mary Joy joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 8000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a single woman with two children – one is attending school while the other is still young for school. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Mwanamisi  has been operating a cashew nut selling business for the past three years, selling at the market to market goers. Mwanamisi faces a major challenge the seasonality of demand in her business. During the rainy season, the demand for cashew nuts is lower compared to other times.  She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan,  Mwanamisi  wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts to resell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase cashew nuts to resell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes B. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  Both of her children are currently in school.  Agnes has a cosmetics shop, which she has had for four years.  She also has a second business selling raw food.  

To help expand her businesses, Agnes has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase cosmetics items and food for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Agnes hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Agnes hopes to own a plot of land and build a house on the plot. 

Agnes is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetic items and food for resale

loans.name: Abdu

texts.en:
K. Abdu lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is widowed and has 4 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of her siblings. 

Abdu has a business making and selling bricks.  She has been in this business for nearly ten years, and works 7 days out of every week. Abdu sells her products from home.  She also generates additional income through plaiting hair.

Abdu has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more firewood. Her goal is for her business to grow well. 

Abdu lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To buy more  firewood

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine K. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. 

Christine operates a retail shop.  She has been in this business for more than seven years, and works 7 days out of every week. Christine sells her products from home.   She also generates additional income through selling piped water and renting out houses.

Christine has requested a loan of 1,300,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, and boxes of soap. 

The main business challenge for Christine is seasonality.  Her goal is to continue to educate her children. Christine lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy soap, salt, and sugar to resell

loans.name: Meriecris

texts.en:
Meriecris is 32 years old.  She is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Meriecris plants and harvests rice and corn for sale. 

Meriecris joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meriecris has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI.  She is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase additional fertilizers and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Rachael has a business of tailoring, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Rachael has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase cloth  for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Rachael hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Rachael hopes to own a plot of land.  Rachael is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money for herself.

loans.use: to purchase cloth  for resale

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith B. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Faith has a business selling decoration flowers, which she has had for five years.  She also has a second business, a boutique, that sells clothes. 

To help expand her businesses, Faith has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase decoration flowers for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Faith hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Faith hopes to own a beauty salon. 

Faith is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money for herself.

loans.use: to purchase decoration flowers for resale

loans.name: Minata Soriba

texts.fr:
Minata Soriba C. est une veuve âgée de 59 ans et mère  de 4 enfants, qui vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec ses enfants, sa coépouse et d’autres parents  au quartier Bougoufiè de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté  l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença tôt le petit commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires.  Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à ses cotés, elle évolue seule pour mener le commerce de poissons frais depuis maintenant 30 ans et jouit d’une grande expérience et notoriété. Sa force de vente est due à la qualité de  ses poissons (gros) qui sont trop appréciés des clients.    
Dans  le but de satisfaire sa demande clientèle, elle rentra en relation avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis 24 mois. Après 2 prêts individuels tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 200 kg de poissons. Il s’approvisionne sur place. Madame Minata Soriba C. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA, qui lui sert à rembourser son prêt et à se nourrir car elle est veuve.
texts.en:
Minata Soriba C. is a widow, 59 years old, and mother of 4 children. She lives in a traditional family with her children, co-wife, and other relatives in the Bougoufie district of the city of Segou (4th most populous administrative region in the republic of Mali).

Not having attended school for social reasons, she started a small business early on beside her mother who sold condiments.  After several years of apprenticeship at her side, she went alone to start a business selling fresh fish. It has now been 30 years and she enjoys a great experience and reputation.  The strength of her sales is due to the quality of her fish (large) that is very much appreciated by her customers.

In order to satisfy customer demand, she has been in a relationship with Soro Yiriwaso for the past 24 months.  After two small individual loans, both completely repaid, she is on her third individual loan that she plans to use for the purchase of 200 kg of fish.  She buys locally. Mrs. Minata Soriba C. sells for cash and for credit to male and female customers.

She expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA, which will allow her to repay her loan and feed herself since she is widowed.

loans.use: Purchase of fish

loans.name: Cheick Ahamed Tidiane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Cheick Ahamed Tidiane T. est âgé de 28 ans,  marié et père de 3 enfants. Il  vit dans une famille nucléaire  avec ses enfants et son épouse au quartier Missira, près de la Medersa de Saada Touré,  dans la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) et dans le souci de s’insérer dans le tissu économique, il  devient apprenti dans un atelier de froid auprès d’un grand frigoriste de Ségou. Après 5 ans d’apprentissage auprès de ce dernier et riche de cette expérience,  il décide d’évoluer seul pour mener le métier de frigoriste. Parallèlement à cette activité, il vend des congélateurs et réfrigérateurs d’occasions et neufs.    
A l’approche  de cette période de chaleur, où il y a de plus de demandes de congélateurs, il décide de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son 1er prêt  qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter, 2 congélateurs. Il s’approvisionne à Gao. 
Monsieur Cheick Ahamed Tidiane T.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA, qui lui sert à rembourser son prêt et à  payer une partie de ses charges de fonctionnement. Son ambition est de développer son secteur d’activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Cheick Ahamed Tidiana T. is 28 years old, married, and has 3 children. He lives in a nuclear family with his children and wife in the Missira area, close to the Medersa de Saada Tourè in the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
Having abandoned his studies during the 9th year of basic classes (in the Malian education system), and with the goal of being part of the local economic community, he became an apprentice in a refrigeration systems workshop run by one of Ségou's biggest refrigeration engineers. After 5 years of training with this expert and having been enriched by this experience, he decided to start his own business as a refrigeration engineer. Along with this business, he sells freezers and refrigerators, both new and second-hand.
With the approach of the hot season, during which there is greater demand for freezers, he decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners). He is on his first loan, which he intends to use to buy 2 freezers. He gets his supplies in Gao.
Mr. Cheick Ahamed Tidiane T. sells his goods in cash and on credit to a clientele composed of men and women.
He intends to realize a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA, which will serve to repay his loan and to pay a portion of his daily expenses. His goal is to further develop his business.

loans.use: To buy freezers

loans.name: Bayasgalan

texts.en:
Bayasgalan is 33 years old, married and has 3 children, ages 3 to 11. They live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  Her husband works as a welder in a local electrical shop.  Her oldest daughter and oldest son attend primary school and her youngest daughter lives with Bayasgalan’s mother-in-law at her mother-in-law’s home. Bayasgalan graduated as a nurse from the Health Sciences University of Ulaanbaatar in 1997.  

Bayasgalan supports her family by operating her two clothing retail stalls at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia.  When she first began her business in 2000, Bayasgalan sold her handmade clothing to customers at home. Her business has grown, and she began to operate her handmade clothing retail stall at Narantuul market in 2005. Her working capital increased and she expanded her stall in 2010. Now she has 2 million Mongolian tugriks (MNT) in working capital at her two clothing stalls, and 800,000 MNT in sewing equipment. 

Bayasgalan sells clothes imported from Ereen as well as her own handmade clothes. She always research new models and the weather, and tries to sew modest and quality clothing.  She is planning to sew many coats for spring during the Mongolian Lunar New Year’s holidays because she will have 15 days off from her clothing stall business during this break.  She is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase clothing materials to make these coats.

Bayasgalan wants to expand her business with this loan investment, and be able to build her own house.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials to sew coats for spring

loans.name: Ningome

texts.en:
Ningome is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Ningome has been operating a soft drinks business for the past year, selling from home to her neighbours and school-going children.  Ningome's main challenge in her business is seasonality. During the rainy season, the demand for natural cold juice is lower compared to the hot summer season. She hopes to be self-reliant in the future.

With the loan for Kshs 60,000, she wants to purchase a deep freezer, fruits and drink flavours. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a deep freezer, fruits and drink flavours

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 5 children, but only  3 are in school.  She also takes care of two grandchildren. 

Rebecca has a  poultry farming business.  She has been in this business for six years, and works six days out of every week. She sells her products in a shop. Rebecca has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more chicken feed and chicks.

The main business challenge for Rebecca is handling customers.  Her goal is to pay for the schooling of all her children. Rebecca lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more chicken feeds and chicks

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice N. lives in Kyebando near the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has eight children – two of her children go to school. 

Beatrice has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for sixteen years, and works seven days out of every week.   Beatrice has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal to resell. 

Beatrice lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expense is school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy charcoal to resell

loans.name: Mwanarusi

texts.en:
Mwanarusi is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She own a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanarusi has been operating a café business for the past two years.  She operates at the market, where market goers and school-going children are her potential customers. Mwanarusi faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 loan, Mwanarusi  wants to purchase sacks of sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, vegetables and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, vegetables and cooking oil

loans.name: Nilben

texts.en:
Nilben M. is from the town of Banga. He is 25 years old. Nilben is married and has 1 child. To make a living, Nilben plants and harvests rice for sale.  He also plants cassavas on parts of his land.

Nilben joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from this investment to improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Duncan

texts.en:
Duncan W. O. is 28 old and married to a business lady. They have two children, aged 6 years and 2 years. They hope to give them a good education to the university level. 

His business is located at Kakamega town. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for the production of sugarcane and it is well known as the sugar belt region. He has been selling groceries and fruits to the local people for the last four years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is the low purchasing power of the customers in the area. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of 70,000 Kenyan shillings to buy mangoes and oranges to grow his business. He hopes to grow his business to a wholesale one. He also sees himself owning a plot of land and building rental houses. He describes himself as a visionary man.

loans.use: Mangoes and oranges

loans.name: Ninfa

texts.en:
Ninfa P. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old. Ninfa is married and has two children, aged 21 and 23. To make a living, Ninfa plants and harvests rice for sale. Ninfa works hard to improve her business.

Ninfa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ninfa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ninfa is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has seven children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of her brother and his children.    

Rose has a business of selling bananas and tomatoes. She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Rose sells her products from home. 

Rose has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (Ush) from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bunches of bananas, tomatoes, cabbage and onions.   

The main business challenge for Rose is rain and the ever-increasing prices of bananas. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to extend the business and save 10,000 Ush each week. 

Rose lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, onions and tomatoes

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past year, selling in a shop and from home to her neighbors. Asha faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in the future. She hopes to access more loans to educate her children in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, sugar, cereals and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans in order to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase stock of wheat flour, sugar, cereals and cooking oil.

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en:
Emilia A. lives in Kapan city with her husband and a son. For about ten years, Emilia has run her own business of selling clothes and shoes in the Kapan clothes market. Once a month, Emilia and her husband go to Yerevan wholesale clothes market to buy men's, women’s and children’s clothes and shoes for Emilia’s business. 

Emilia says children's shoes are in good demand in any season, so she tries to place an emphasis on selling children’s shoes.

Emilia asks for a $1,300 loan to buy a spring assortment for her business.

loans.use: To buy a spring assortment for her business

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  Both of her children are currently in school.  Joy has a poultry firm, which she has had for six years.  She also has a second  business selling tap water.  

To help expand her business, Joy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Joy hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  

In the future, Joy hopes to expand her business by building another house for the chickens.  Joy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money and get new friends.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for resale

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace Adong lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is widowed and has no children. She takes care of her brother's children. Grace has a business of selling local brew. She has been in this business for seven years, and she works seven days every week. Grace sells her local brew on retail and at the market. Grace has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of millet and sorghum for making local brew.

The main business challenge for Grace is a low profit margin as well as transport and defaulters. Her goal is to one day build a house. Grace lives in a home that she rents; she does not have access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees for her brother's children and transport of sugar.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sorghum and millet for making local brew

loans.name: Getrude

texts.en:
Getrude N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has four children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Getrude has a business selling soft drinks, which she has had for one year.  She also has a second business washing clothes.  

To help expand her businesses, Getrude has requested a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more soft  drinks for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Getrude hopes to generate greater profits and sometimes pay school fees for her children.  

In the future, Getrude hopes to own a retail shop. Getrude is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by encouraging her to be independent and to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Samira

texts.en:
Samira is a married woman with five children. Three of her children attend school, while two are still young for school. Samira owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Samira has operated a cashew nut selling business for the past five years, selling at the market to town dwellers. Samira faces a major challenge of high competition from other cashew nut sellers and seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business and sell as wholesale in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale

loans.name: Yudaya

texts.en:
Yudaya N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Yudaya has a small retail shop that sells new clothes, which she has had for five years.  She also has a second business selling soft drinks  

To help expand her businesses, Yudaya has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes and drinks for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Yudaya hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. 

 In the future, Yudaya hopes to own a plot of land. Yudaya is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to improve her business and get new friends

loans.use: to purchase more clothes and drinks for resale

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has no children. Jessica has a business selling clothes in the market, which she has had for three years.         

To help expand her business, Jessica has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jessica hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her sister.  

In the future, Jessica hopes to own a boutique with clothes. Jessica is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 53 years old, married and has four children. 

Mohamad grew up in a family which owns a farm. In 2002, he established his own cattle farm. He has an excellent reputation in his area.

Mohamad is requesting $2400 loan to renovate the cowshed and buy a cow. He is planning to extend his business and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To renovate the cowshed and buy a cow

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah N. lives in the Nabukalu neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has six children, and all her children go to school. Hadjah changed her business from selling donuts, samosas and chapats to selling charcoal. She works seven days a week. Hadjah sells her products at the market. She has been in this business for a few months.

Hadjah has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags charcoal. The main business challenge for Hadjah is transportation. Hadjah lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity and doesn’t have access to piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Mwanakame

texts.en:
Mwanakame is a married woman with three children. Two of her children attend school, while one is still young for school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Mwanakame has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Mwanakame faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. She hopes to sell as wholesale in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, cooking fat oil, sugar and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, cooking fat oil, sugar and rice

loans.name: Saf Nieup Group

texts.fr:
le groupe de solidarité SAF NIEUP est créé depuis un an et demi. Il est composé de 29 femmes qui sont toutes issues du même village. Le groupe fait partie du Banc Villageois de THIO ADI

Madame Khady S. debout au milieu du groupe sur la photo et mise en médaillon est responsable du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. elle a aussi la charge de deux autres enfants qui lui sont confiés par des proches. 

Elle fait un petit commerce de lait caillé. Trois fois par semaine elle se rend dans les grandes villes telles que Rufisque pour vendre du lait caillé. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de 20 ans.

Elle soutient son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille: par exemple le payement des fournitures scolaires pour les enfants. Elle participe également aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille
texts.en:
The SAF NIEUP solidarity group was created a year and a half ago. It consists of 29 women, all from the same village. The group is part of the Banc Villageois of THIO ADI.

Mrs. Khady S. is the head of the group. She appears in the photo standing in the center of the group, and also inset. She is married with five children, and also looks after two other children who have been entrusted to her care.  

She has a small business selling milk curd. Three times a week, she travels to large cities such as Rufisque to sell milk curd. She has been doing this for over 20 years. 

She assists her husband with the family responsibilities including the payment of school supplies for the children. She also helps with the daily expenses.

loans.use: To sustain her small business of milk curd sales

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, and all her children go to school. Juliet has a business selling poultry. She has been in this business for 18 years, and she works seven days a week. Juliet sells her products at the market and from home. 

Juliet has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy chicken feed. Juliet lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of chicken feed

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick K. A. is 30 years old and married to a businesswoman. They have three children between the ages of eight years old and two years old, and they hope to give their children a good education to the university level. 

Erick's business is located at the busy Kakamega Shinyalu road. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugarcane, and it is well known as the sugar belt region. Erick provides motorcycle transportation services to the local people. He has been in this business for the past two years and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is poor roads, which become almost impassable during the rainy seasons. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to purchase a motorbike to grow his business. He hopes to grow his business and he sees himself owning a fleet of motorbikes for business. He also sees himself owning a plot of land. He describes himself as a visionary man.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike in order to grow his business

loans.name: Houssein

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 25 years old, married and has three children. In 2008, Houssein opened his own food market in an area where the competition is minimal. He is well known in his community and has an excellent reputation.

Houssein is requesting an $1800 loan to install an external ceiling, put up a sign at the entrance and buy a refrigerator. He is aiming to extend his business and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To install an external ceiling, put up a sign at the entrance and buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Kathem

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 35 years old, married and has three children. Kathem opened his own food market in 2006 since he has good experience in this business. He is well known in his community and has a good reputation.

Kathem is requesting a $2400 loan to buy a generator and a motorcycle for delivery. He is aiming to extend his business and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To buy a generator and a motorcycle

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 28 years old, married and has one child. He has been doing car bodywork for so long that he has good experience in this field. In 2007, Haidar opened his own workshop. Now he is well known and has an excellent reputation.

Haidar is requesting a $2400 loan to install a new ceiling and shutters for the shop. He is aiming to develop and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To install a new ceiling and shutters

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with two children. One child attends school, while the other one is still too young for school. Fatuma owns a house that has electricity, but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Fatuma has operated a vegetable selling business for the past year, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Fatuma faces a major challenge of competition from other vegetable stall sellers. She hopes to expand her business and increase sales in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes, onions and fruit. She decided to work with Yehu to access loans and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables, tomatoes, onions and fruit

loans.name: Zulaika

texts.en:
Zulaika N. lives in the Kawempe neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of her mother. 

Zulaika has a business of selling matooke (a local dish made from bananas). She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days a week. Zulaika sells her products from home. Zulaika has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bunches of bananas. The main business challenge for Zulaika is transportation and seasonality. Her goal is to create another branch of her business. 

Zulaika lives in a home that she owns; she does not access to electricity or to piped water. Her major monthly expense is school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma W. lives in the Nabukalu neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom go to school. She lives in a home that she rents, with access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.
Fatuma sells traditional medicine and herbs. She has been in this business for five years, and works six days a week. The main business challenges she faces are theft and transportation problems. Fatuma sells her products door to door. She has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO. She wants to use this loan to go and buy local herbs from villages in Masaka District.

loans.use: To buy more local herbs

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet S. lives in the Naguru neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. Annet lives in a home that she owns, with access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses are school fees, food and medical bills.
Annet has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for 16 years, and works seven days a week. She sells her products from home. Annet has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from Kiva partner, MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through selling food. The main business challenge she faces is seasonality. Her goals are to help her children go to school and to eat, and to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sope Aladj Barra Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPE ALADJ BARRA est créé depuis le 27 juin 2007, au jour de l'inauguration du Banc Villageois de SINOU KHALY qui l'abrit. Il est constitué de 19 femmes qui sont toutes du même village. Elles se sont regroupées par affinité et par voisinage.

Madame DABA S. au milieu du groupe en pagne raillé de couleurs multiples, dont son médaillon est mis en dessous est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 33 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants.

Elle fait un commerce d'habits. Elle vend dans le village des robes de dames et vêtements pour enfants et bébés. Elle pratique cette activité depuis plus de trois ans. 

Son nouveau lui permettra de mieux développer son activité en augmentant son niveau d'approvisionnement en achetant plus de tissus pour la confection des robes et vêtements pour enfants et bébés

Avec les bénéfices que génère son activité elle parvient à acheter du riz et payer souvent des frais médicaux pour ses enfants.
texts.en:
The business group SOPE ALADJ BARRA was created on June 27 2007, the day of the inauguration of the Village Bank of SINOU KHALY that houses it.   It consists of 19 women who are all from the same village.  They are grouped by affinity and neighborhood.

Mrs. DABA S., in the middle of the group wearing the multicolored outfit, with her medallion placed below, is the manager of the group.  She is 33 years old, married, and mother of 3 children.

She is in the clothing business. In the village, she sells women’s dresses and clothing for infants and children.  She has been in this business for more than three years.

Her new loan will enable her to expand her business and increase her level of merchandise by buying more fabric for making dresses and clothing for babies and children.

With the profits generated by her business, she manages to buy rice and frequently pay her children’s medical expenses.

loans.use: Expand and promote her small business

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita P. is 53 years old and lives in Kapan city. She is a widow and her only son lives in Russia with his family. For about 12 years Rita has run a clothes and shoes trading business. She buys merchandise from Yerevan once a week and resells it from a rented stall in Kapan clothes market. Rita is able to support herself with this business.
Rita is asking for a $1,000 loan to buy spring season clothes and shoes for her business. This is Rita’s eighth loan from Kiva partner, Nor Horizon, and she has never made a late loan repayment.

loans.use: To buy spring season clothes and shoes for her business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan W. G. is married to a Jua kali ('hot sun'; outdoor) artisan. They have two children, aged 13 and 18, to whom they wish to give a quality education to university level.
Susan owns a big bus for passenger transport in Nairobi. Besides this business she grows and sells horticultural crops. She has been in this business for seven years now and has managed to provide employment to two people. She says that her business is profitable and the major challenge she faces is harassment by the corrupt traffic police. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 50,000 KES to buy farm inputs for her horticultural business. In the future, she hopes to own more buses for transport. She also sees herself owning a plot of land on which she will build a house for her family. She describes herself as focused, determined and goal oriented.

loans.use: To purchase inputs for her horticultural farm

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school while one is too young for school. She owns a house that is without both electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.
Mwanamisi has operated a vegetable selling business for the past two years, selling from home to neighbors and passers-by. She faces the major challenge of competition from other vegetable stall operators. She hopes to establish a reliable business in the future. With this 20,000 KES loan, Mwanamisi wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale. She decided to join Kiva partner, Yehu, to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables for resale

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy W. is a married lady. Her husband is an electrician, and they have six children aged between 24 years old and 2 years old. 

She runs a food cafe and sells such snacks as chips, sausage, samosas, eggs and chicken to the local people. Her business is located in a residential area known as Huruma in Nairobi. She has been in this business for 15 years now and has managed to provide employment to four people. 

She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is power outages. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 50,000 KES to open another food cafe in an area called Chokaa.

 In the future, she hopes to venture into the real estate business. She describes herself as hard-working, determined, generous and God-fearing.

loans.use: Open a food cafe

loans.name: Eseza

texts.en:
Eseza T. lives in the Kisasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of orphans. 

Eseza deals in second-hand clothes.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Eseza sells her products at the market. Eseza has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes.

The main business challenge for Eseza is transportation.  Eseza lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and to piped water.  Her major monthly expense is school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

She has operated an open food stall business for the past year, selling from her home to her neighbors and passers-by. Fatuma faces a major challenge of competition from other food stall operators. She hopes to be a reliable seller in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, sacks of sugar, cooking oil and coconuts. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, sacks of sugar, cooking oil and coconuts.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margret N. lives in the Kisasi neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has four children and all her children go to school. 

Margret has a business of selling bananas.  She has been in this business for 16 years, and she works seven days out of every week. Margret sells her products at the market. Margret has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO and wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.

The main business challenge for Margret is transportation.  Margret lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity but not to piped water.  Her major monthly expense is school fees and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bunches  of bananas

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a widowed woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a restaurant business for the past five months, her potential customers are the market-goers. Asha faces a major challenge of competition from other restaurant operators in her business.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, rice, cooking fat, oil and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, wheat flour, rice, cooking fat, oil and sugar.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman who owns a house that has electricity but not running water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. For the past ten years, Asha has operated a cashew nut selling business. She sells cashews at the market to her neighbors and community members. Her major business challenge is seasonality. 

Asha decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood. She is requesting a loan of 25,000 KES to purchase sacks of cashew nuts. In the future, Asha hopes to be a reliable supplier of cashews.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashews

loans.name: Sofya

texts.en: Sofya M. is 44 years old and lives in the Tsovagyugh village, Sevan area, with her husband and son. Sofya’s family has been engaged in farming for 20 years. They raise cows, sheep, pigs, and chickens on their farm. Sofya and her family are very dedicated to their work and, thanks to their hard work, they are able to keep and develop their farm. Sofya is requesting a 500,000 AMD loan to buy calves for her farm.

loans.use: to buy calves

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase coral blocks for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 26-year-old married man living with his wife and one young child. He is from Lebanon. He has owned a communication and mobile phones shop since 2006. In parallel, he works in the national police department. In Lebanon, it’s frequent to have multiple jobs to be able to support the heavy living expenses. He has obtained two Kiva loans and he was an excellent client with prompt payments.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to enlarge his shop’s inventory so he can augment his sales and as a result obtain higher profits.

loans.use: to enlarge his shop’s inventory

loans.name: Tunashukuru Group

texts.fr: Karubamba F. est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe d’affaire Tunashukuru, âgée de 38 ans, mariée, mère de 12 enfants qui étudient tous, sauf le cadet. Son marie est un agent de la fonction publique. La cliente  Karubamba F. est  vendeuse des boissons (Fanta, Primus). Elle s’installe dans un dépôt relais. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds propre reçu de son mari. Il ya 4 ans qu’elle est en activité. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de payer les frais scolaires de ses enfants.  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, et scolariser ses enfants confortablement. La cliente Karubamba F. remercie Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Tunashukuru est constitué de 45 membres.
texts.en: Karubamba F. is an entrepreneur, president of the business group Tunashukuru, 38 years old, married, and the mother of 12 children- all of whom are in school except for the youngest.  Her husband is a civil servant.  Karubamba F. sells beverages (Fanta, Primus).  She has set up shop in a small restaurant in a bus depot.  She started her own business with funds from her husband.  She has been in business for four years.  This new loan will enable her to pay the school fees for her children.  In addition, she hopes to grow her enterprise and educate her children comfortably.  Karubamba F. thanks Hekima for its initiatives dedicated to poor women excluded from formal banks.  The Tunashukuru Group is made up of 45 members.

loans.use: Paying school fees for children

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Eseza

texts.en:
Eseza N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom go to school. Eseza also takes care of orphans and her mother. She lives in a rented home that has electricity but no running water. Her major monthly expenses are school fees and rent.

Eseza runs a salon and cosmetics business. She has been in this business for eight years, and she works seven days out of every week. Her major business challenge is seasonality. Eseza has requested a loan of 800,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics

loans.name: Harifah

texts.en:
Harifah N. lives in the Nakamiro neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is single and has six children, all of whom go to school. She lives in a rented home and has access to running water.

Harifah runs a business selling spare motor parts in a shop. She has been in this business for three years and she works six days a week. Harifah’s main business challenge is seasonality. She is requesting a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO to add inventory to her business. Harifah’s future goal is to have her own school.

loans.use: to buy inventory

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with three children, all of whom are adults. She owns a house that has electricity but no running water and her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. For the past ten years, Mwanasiti has operated a retail shop, selling goods at the market to her neighbors and community members. Her major business challenge is seasonality. 

Mwanasiti decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a 30,000 KES loan to purchase sacks of wheat flour, sugar, rice and beans to sell. In the future, Mwanasiti hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, sugar, rice, and beans

loans.name: Umucyo Group

texts.en:
Emima, 68 years old, is part of the Umucyo (a Kinyarwanda word meaning "light") group. A mother of eight children between the ages of 8-36 years old, she has been able to provide an education for only some of them due to financial limitations. Emima sells a variety of foodstuffs, a business she has enjoyed for 35 years. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more foodstuffs, and she plans to keep her profits for savings.

Most of the other group members also sell foodstuffs, while others sell a variety of items such as fruits and vegetables, sugar, flour and other home items.

loans.use: Buying food stuffs.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N., who lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda, is married and has seven children, all of whom go to school. She also takes care of her mother. For the past two years Margret has had a used clothing business, selling her products at the market six days a week. She is now requesting a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO in order to buy more clothes.

The main business challenge Margret faces is thieves. Her immediate goal is to pay the school fees for her children. Margret lives in a home that she owns with access to electricity but no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, transport, and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothing

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 58-year-old married man and the father of two school-aged children. He is from Lebanon. He has worked in a local food company since 2002. He cooperates with his wife who owns an accessories shop to satisfy the family needs.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to pay for his children's education. In that way, he will avoid facing financial problems with the school management and permit his children to pursue their education peacefully.

loans.use: to pay for his children's education

loans.name: David

texts.en: David, a 64-year-old carpenter, has been making furniture for four years. He has managed to educate his children.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to grow his business and thus improve his standard of living.  David hopes to develop a big carpentry business and become a successful businessman in the future.  He is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kes to buy more timber.

loans.use: To buy more timber

loans.name: Allen

texts.en: Allen  is 28 years, married to a soldier, and the mother of three children between the ages of 6 months and 6 years. Allen has operated a business selling secondhand children's clothes for six years. Allen is requesting a loan in order to buy more secondhand clothes. She plans to use the profits from the loan to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy clothes

loans.name: Marie Chantal

texts.en: Marie Chantal, 36, is married to a mototaxi driver and has 4 children between the ages of 4 and 10 years old. Two of her children go to school. Marie has been operating a business selling foodstuffs such as green bananas, beans, rice and sugar for 7 years . She is requesting a loan to purchase more foodstuffs which will enable her to make more profits.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Darou Salam Tacku Liguey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité DAROU SALAM TACKU LIGUEY est créé le 27 juin 2007 au jour d'inauguration du Banc Villageois de SINOU KHALY qui l'abrite. Il est composé de 23 femmes qui sont toutes du même village. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame NDEYE G. debout à l'extrême droite de la photo de rose vêtue avec une écharpe noire est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 33 ans. Elle est célibataire et mère de 03 enfants. 

Elle fait du petit commerce. Elle vend des produits divers tels du mil, de l'huile, de l'arachide et du sucre. 

Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de renforcer son activité afin d'accroitre ses bénéfices.

Son objectif est d'assurer la prise en charge de la nourriture, de la santé et scolaire de sa progéniture
texts.en:
The Darou Salam Tacku Liguey Solidarity Group was created on 27 June 2007 on the inaugural day of the Sinou Khaly Village Bank, to which it belongs.  It is made up of 23 women from the same village.  Their main business is petty trading.

Mrs. Ndeye G., who stands at the far right of the photo in the pink top with the black scarf, is responsible for the group.  She is 33 years old.  She is a single mother of three children.  She is a small-businesswoman.  She sells various products such as millet, oil, groundnuts and sugar.  

Her new loan will allow her to strengthen her business in order to increase profits.  Her goal is to secure the food, health, and education of her offspring.

loans.use: Buying millet, groundnuts, oil and sugar

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is divorced with two grown children. She is an entrepreneur from Ivano-Frankivsk. Nataliya used to work as a deputy director in a knitting factory. However, it was closed down and she was forced to launch her own business. 

Now, Nataliya sells men’s suits, pants, and shirts in the central marketplace of her hometown. She offers a nice selection of assorted inventory at affordable prices. Nataliya has been in this trade for 11 years and this business is the main source of income for her. Her monthly profit amounts to 6,000 UAH. Recently Nataliya opened a second location to increase her sales.

Nataliya is seeking a loan of 20,000 UAH to purchase 40 spring coats as well as some men’s pants for further retail sale. She uses some of her income to help her daughter (who is a third year student) pay for college.

loans.use: to purchase assorted merchandise

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, who attend school. Florence has been operating a restaurant for over ten years, and she works seven days a week. Florence also sells her products in a shop. Florence has access to electricity but doesn’t have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

Florence has requested a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy a deep freezer. Florence's main business challenges include seasonality and thieves. Her goals and hopes for her business are to eventually buy a plot of land.

loans.use: to buy a deep freezer

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 40 years old and the father of two children. He sells electronic goods for a living.  He also does dairy farming to supplement his family’s income. James started his business in 1995 and has witnessed its growth through Faulu Kenya, hence improving his standard of living. He hopes that someday he will become a successful businessman. He will use the 70,000 KES loan to buy a television.

loans.use: to buy a television

loans.name: Silvio

texts.en: Mr. Silvio Martinez is married and the father of grown children. He has his own house. His wife makes aopo'i (loose-weave cotton) clothing. He has been selling her goods by motorcycle in the Pilar area for over 5 years. Mr. Silvio Martinez is requesting a loan to buy fabrics, pins, buttons, thread, etc. so his wife can make more clothes. He thanks the Paraguayan Foundation for providing loan assistance.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, pins, buttons, thread, etc.

loans.name: Yudaya

texts.en:
Yudaya N. lives in her own home in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has six children. She also takes care of her grandchildren. Yudaya has access to electricity and to piped water. Her major monthly expenses are rent and school fees.

Yadaya has operated a food stall in the market for six years, and she works seven days a week. Yudaya has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO. Yudaya's main business challenge is seasonality.

loans.use: food to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old divorced woman from Lebanon.  She lives with her parents and three siblings. Eight years ago, she established a tailoring business out of her home to help her father with the family income. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional textiles in order to expand her business operation and earn more profit.

loans.use: to expand her business operation

loans.name: Marion

texts.en: Marion, 33 years old, is married and has two children, both of whom attend school. She is a member of the Hope Self Help group with Faulu Kenya. Marion runs a salon for a living and works hard in her business. She joined the Faulu Kenya group so that she could access financial resources easily. She has certainly benefited because she has managed to build her own house with her previous loans from Faulu Kenya. Marion is looking forward to opening a cosmetic shop in the future. Marion needs 60,000 KES to buy hair chemicals, hair extensions and cosmetics.

loans.use: to buy hair chemicals, hair extensions and cosmetics

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a widowed woman with six children, all adults now. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Fatuma has operated a business selling cashew nuts for the past fifteen years. She sells at the market to her neighbors and market dwellers. Fatuma faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. Fatuma plans to use the 30,000 KES loan to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her livelihood.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts

loans.name: Leopold

texts.en: N. Leopold, 42 years old, is a happily married man with 4 children. His source of livelihood is a banana sales business in Nyabitete food market-Rukungiri. The business is lucrative since bananas are a staple food, especially in western Uganda. Leopold combines this business with coffee sales and it is actually the profits from the coffee sales that enabled him to start his current business, which he finds more worthwhile due to the large number of people who purchase bananas weekly and especially on market days. Leopold says this business brings in 190,000 UGX as profit. He is requesting this loan to pay for more space at the market so that he can expand his business operations.

loans.use: to rent more space to expand his business

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married, has one child and makes a living selling women's clothing from a kiosk in a local market. Her location is a good one, because it allows her to reach out to people who come to the market for necessities such as food. She started her business six years ago and tapped into expertise acquired by her mother, who had a lot of sales experience. 

Irina would like to borrow 17,500 Ukrainian Grivnas to increase the range of items she has for sale. She would also like to open a second store where she could sell seeds and fertilizers, which will be in high demand during the upcoming spring planting season.

loans.use: to increase the range of clothing items she has for sale

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane N. lives in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has six children, all of whom go to school. For the last 28 years, she has made a living by selling clothes, working six days a week in a small shop.
